meanings.def: a large deep hole in the ground
examples: We dug a deep pit in the yard.
The body had been dumped in a pit.
(figurative) The human mind is a dark, bottomless pit.

meanings.def: a deep hole in the ground from which minerals are dug out
examples: a chalk/gravel pit
They extract the mineral from open pits and underground mines.
a disused gravel pit

meanings.def: a place underground where coal is dug
examples: pit closures
(British English) He went down the pit (= started work as a miner) when he left school.
Most boys in the town worked in the pits.
There's no more work in these pit villages.

meanings.def: a small shallow hole in the surface of something, especially a mark left on the surface of the skin by some disease, such as chickenpox
a hard shell containing the nut or seed in the middle of some types of fruit
examples: a peach pit

meanings.def: a place near the track where cars can stop for fuel, new tyres, etc. during a race
the place in a theatre just in front of the stage where the orchestra sits and plays for an opera, a ballet, etc.
an armpit (= the part of the body under the arm where it joins the shoulder)
the area of a stock exchange where a particular product is traded
examples: the corn pit

meanings.def: to be very bad or the worst example of something
a thing or situation which seems to have no limits or seems never to end
examples: There isn't a bottomless pit of money for public spending.
the bottomless pit of his sorrow

meanings.def: the bottom of the stomach where people say they feel strong feelings, especially fear
examples: He had a sudden sinking feeling in the pit of his stomach.
I felt a sickening feeling in the pit of my stomach when I saw the ambulance.

idioms.def: to be very bad or the worst example of something
a thing or situation which seems to have no limits or seems never to end
examples: There isn't a bottomless pit of money for public spending.
the bottomless pit of his sorrow

idioms.def: the bottom of the stomach where people say they feel strong feelings, especially fear
examples: He had a sudden sinking feeling in the pit of his stomach.
I felt a sickening feeling in the pit of my stomach when I saw the ambulance.

meanings.def: to make marks or holes on the surface of something
examples: pit something Smallpox scars had pitted his face.
be pitted with something The surface of the moon is pitted with craters.

meanings.def: to remove the stone from the inside of a fruit
examples: pitted olives
